name: Emacs
description:
I use [Emacs](https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/), [heavily customized](https://github.com/NateEag/.emacs.d), as my text editor.

It's not for everyone, but if what you want is power, flexibility, and sustainability, Vim is probably the only contender.

...though I do use `evil-mode`.

The [Language Server Protocol](https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/) means that I get decent auto-completion and jump-to-definition in most languages I use. It's not quite as good as some first-rate IDEs, but the gap is mostly in arcane features specific to a given language.

name: Scheme
description:
I don't have a record of when my college programming language theory class was, but that's when I first met Scheme (2004 is most likely).

I've actually used it professionally, and no, it wasn't nearly as cool as that sounds.

name: MySQL
description:
MySQL 5 is a powerful tool with a number of sharp edges and errors in its design (the `utf8mb4` charset's existence comes to mind, but [there are many other issues](http://grimoire.ca/mysql/choose-something-else)). I have used it on many projects over the years but don't love it.

I understand MySQL 8 solved a lot of the worst issues, but I prefer PostGreSQL.
